Award.AwardTitle: NUE: Enhancing Undergraduate Students' Learning and Research Experiences through Hands on Experiments on Bio-nanoengineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) in Engineering program entitled, "NUE: Enhancing Undergraduate Students Learning and Research Experiences through Hands on Experiments on Bio-nanoengineering", at North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University (NCAT), under the direction of Dr. Narayan Bhattarai, will bring together a team of interdisciplinary faculty members from the Department of Chemical and Bioengineering, Department of Mechanical Engineering and the Department of Chemistry to enhance undergraduate student learning in bioengineering by introducing training on devices and systems that integrate nanoscale technologies with biological systems for the development of new materials, biomimetic nanostructures and tools.

NCAT's College of Engineering is consistently among the top two producers of African-American engineers in the nation. The proposed NUE project is expected to provide a significant number of underrepresented minority students with training and mentoring focused on bio-nanoengineering. Further the undergraduate students impacted by this program are expected to add to the talent pool for NCAT's graduate programs in traditional as well as in nontraditional engineering and science disciplines such as Bioengineering, Nanoscience and Nanoengineering, and Computational Science and Engineering.

Institution.Name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRICULTURAL AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University

ProgramReference.Text: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project takes into account the need for a better marriage between theory, experiment and applications. Saveral hands-on exposures are being provided to students in the areas of bionanotechnology and nano-systems, characterization and measurement of nanostructured systems and devices. Biomedical nanotechnology course modules are developed in in existed two undgraduate bioengineering required courses (Bio-Nano I).  An interdisciplinary nanotechnology course (Bio-Nano II) with a significant hands-on laboratory component has been developed. This course is offered as a technical elective and is open to all engineering majors. A selected number of undergraduate students who have foundational perspective on nanotechnology from previous two initiatives i.e. Bio-Nano I and II are engaged in a semester-long nanomaterials research project under a course called Bio-Nano III. Students who have completed all these three courses along with attending nanotechnology seminars have received certificate of Interdisciplinary Bionano Engineering Course Sequence. A certificate program entitled with “Interdisciplinary Bionano Engineering Certificate” has received approval form College of Engineering, and is waiting for final approval from the University. The current NUE project have impacted over 100 undergraduate students (over 80% of them are minority) in the last two years via introduction of modules in two existed core courses.  The project has impacted additional 40 undergraduate students per year via two new courses in the area of nanotechnology (Bio-Nano II and III). The project has also provided opportunities over 15 undergraduate students to work on nanoscience and nanoengineering related projects that include 6 through in the summer of 2014 and 2015.


Last Modified: 12/30/2015
Modified by: Narayan Bhattarai
